isis.stitle: TSI 94-16-03R - Installation of High Roof and Low Roof 51 Inch and 72 Inch Roof Air Deflector Assemblies

subjectgroup.subject: Installation of High Roof and Low Roof 51 Inch and 72 Inch Roof Air Deflector Assemblies

geninfo.para: Navistar is now producing high roof and low roof 51 inch and 72 inch PRO SLEEPERS. The roof air deflector and upper side deflector assemblies for these vehicles are shipped directly to the dealer for painting and installation. The following includes instructions to paint and install the air deflector assemblies, along with information to handle claims for a damaged shipment.

svcproc.title: PAINTING
svcproc.para: Roof air deflectors, air deflector extenders and satellite antenna mounts (where required) will be supplied unpainted. Refer to PRIME AND TOPCOAT PAINTING FIBERGLASS section for painting information.

step1.para: Prepare the outer surface of the air deflector and air deflector extenders for painting as explained in the painting instructions.
Paint the air deflector and side deflectors the finish color before installation. The inside of the air deflector and the back side of the air deflector extenders do not require a class 1 finish.

important.para: Completely cover the roof of the cab with blankets or tarps to protect the roof from being damaged during the installation procedure.

step1.para: Remove the cab drag link airshield brace from the air deflector middle and rear mounting brackets on both sides of the vehicle ( Figure 1). Re-install the bolt that secures the middle mounting bracket to the cab roof. Tighten finger tight.
Position the air deflector on the air deflector front mounting bracket tabs ( Figure 2), then slide the air deflector back against the air deflector rear mounting brackets ( Figure 2).
Re-install the cab drag link airshield brace between the middle mounting bracket and the air deflector ( Figure 1). Install and tighten the bolt on the middle mounting bracket finger tight.

Install two 3/8" x 1-1/2" hex hd. bolts and 3/8" flat washers through the two holes in the air deflector rear mounting bracket, through the rear of the air deflector and cab drag link airshield brace on both sides of the vehicle ( Figure 2). Install a 3/8" nylon insert locknut and 3/8" flat washer on each bolt. Tighten the locknuts until they are snug and the air deflector is against both air deflector rear mounting brackets.

With the air deflector resting on the front mounting tabs, measure the clearance between the front of the air deflector and the cab roof. The clearance across the front should be 3/4 of an inch ( Figure 3). If it's not close to 3/4 of an inch, block the front of the air deflector up to obtain the correct clearance. Be sure the measurement is the same across the front of the air deflector ( Figure 3).

note.para: If you plan on installing more than one set of PRO SLEEPER ® air deflector assemblies, it is recommended that metal templates be made from the drawings Figure 11 and Figure 12.

step1.para: Place the drilling templates in position on the tabs of the air deflector front mounting bracket as illustrated in Figure 4. Be sure the slot in the template is resting on the tab ( Figure 4). Tape the template in this position.
Drill a 1/8 inch pilot hole through the air deflector in both positions indicated on the template.

Remove the template and drill a 13/32 inch hole through the air deflector in both pilot hole locations. Care should be taken not to damage the threads in the air deflector front mounting bracket when the drill passes through the fiberglass material of the air deflector.

Install a 3/8" x 1-3/4" star drive bolt and 3/8 inch flat washer in both holes and tighten finger tight ( Figure 5). If the bolts are difficult to install, run a 3/8"-16 tap in the holes to clean up the threads.

Be sure the middle mounting bracket is against the inside of the air deflector ( Figure 5) and use the 1/8" pilot drill to drill a hole (from the inside) at each bolt hole location in both air deflector middle mounting brackets ( Figure 5).
From outside the air deflector, drill a 11/32" hole at each 1/8" pilot hole.
Install, from the outside, a 3/8" x 1-3/4" star drive bolt and flat washer through the air deflector and mounting bracket. Secure with a 3/8"-16 nylon insert locknut and flat washer ( Figure 5).
Repeat steps 10 through 12 on the opposite side of the vehicle.
Tighten all air deflector front and middle star drive mounting bolts and the middle mounting bracket mounting bolt to 31 ft-lbs. (42 N•m).
Remove the two 3/8 inch bolts from the rear mounting bracket, through the rear of the air deflector ( Figure 6).

Position the right air deflector extender to the right rear of the roof air deflector so the bottom two holes in the side deflector line up with the two lower holes in the air deflector rear mounting bracket ( Figure 6).
Re-install the two 3/8 inch bolts, flat washers and nuts removed in step one in these holes ( Figure 6).
Position the side deflector so it is flush with the side and top of the roof air deflector ( Figure 7). Hold in place with a "C" clamp ( Figure 6). Tighten the two lower nuts to 31 ft-lbs. (42 N•m).
Use the holes in the mounting flange of the air deflector extender as a template and drill a 11/32 inch hole through the roof air deflector at each hole location ( Figure 7).

From the air deflector extender side. install a 5/16" x 1" hex hd. bolt and 5/16 inch flat washer through each hole. Install a 5/16 inch dished flat washer and nylon insert lock nut on each bolt ( Figure 7). Tighten to 18 ft-lbs. (24 N•m). Remove the "C" clamp.
Repeat steps 1 through 6 on the left air deflector extender.

Position the "L" bracket on the inside of the lower side air deflector and up against the bottom of the air deflector extender as illustrated in Figure 8. Secure in place with two 5/16"-18 x 1" hex hd. bolts and 5/16" lock washers. Tighten hand tight.

Use the hole on the side of the "L" bracket that is against the bottom of the air deflector extender as a guide to drill a 11/32" hole through the bottom of the air deflector extender ( Figure 8). Secure the "L" bracket to the air deflector extender with a 5/16"-18 x 1" hex hd. bolt, flat washer, lock washer and hex nut through this hole with the head of the bolt and flat washer against the air deflector extender ( Figure 8). Tighten the fasteners to 18 ft-lbs. (24 N•m).
Remove the 7th and 8th bolts (from the bottom going up) that secures the air deflector extender to the roof air deflector and discard.
Place antenna mount against side deflector and align with the holes of the bolts removed in step one ( Figure 9).

Install a 5/16" x 1-1/4" hex hd. bolt and 5/16 inch flat washer through these holes into the roof air deflector. Install a 5/16 inch flat washer, lock washer and locknut on each bolt ( Figure 9). Tighten to 18 ft-lbs. (24 N•m).

Drill a 11/32 inch hole through the roof air deflector using the outermost hole in the antenna mount as a guide ( Figure 9). Install a 5/16" x 1-1/4" hex hd. bolt and 5/16 inch flat washer through this hole into the roof air deflector. Install a 5/16 inch flat washer, lock washer and locknut on the bolt. Tighten to 18 ft-lbs. (24 N•m).

Drill two 11/32 inch holes through the side air deflector using the holes in the antenna mount that contact the side deflector as a guide ( Figure 9). Install 5/16" x 1-1/4" button hd. capscrews and 5/16 inch flat washers through the holes in the side air deflector into the antenna mount. Install 5/16 inch flat washers, lock washers and locknuts on the bolts. Tighten to 18 ft-lbs. (24 N•m).
Bolt antenna to the antenna mount with the fasteners supplied with the antenna.
Run cable using "P" clamps or wire ties as required to insure that they do not vibrate, especially next to the antenna plugs.
Check antenna operation per manufacturer's instructions included with the antenna.
Hold the flexible cab trim molding in position against the rear edge of the air deflector extender assembly ( Figure 10).

Install No. 10 fasteners starting from the center and working out toward each end as illustrated in Figure 10. Snug up each fastener. Align the forward edge of the flexible molding flush with the outside trailing edge of the air deflector extender assembly.
Tighten all fasteners from the center out to 6 ft-lbs. (8 N•m). Do not over tighten as distortion of the flexible molding and retainer may result.

svcproc.title: DRILLING TEMPLATES FOR 51 INCH PRO SLEEPER
svcproc.para: It will be necessary to create metal templates to use as a guide to drill the front bracket mounting holes in the air deflector (step 6 under AIR DEFLECTOR INSTALLATION). One template can be made using the right side measurements. Reverse the right template to use it on the left side.

These templates are full size. DO NOT COPY. Copying will change their size causing mislocation of the drilling holes in the air deflector. Dimensions are included to allow making metal templates for repeated use. Thickness of the templates should be 1/8 inch or less.

step1.para: Remove the 5/16"-18 torx hd. capscrews installed around the high roof ( Figure 13).
Carefully set the roof air deflector on the roof so that the holes in the air deflector line up with the holes in the roof ( Figure 14).

caution.para: Care should be taken not to mar the paint on the roof during air deflector installation.

step1.para: Re-install the 5/16"-18 torx hd. capscrews that were removed in step 1 to secure the air deflector to the roof ( Figure 14). Tighten to 18 ft-lbs. (24 N•m).

Install the left and right flexible cab trim molding to the rear of both air deflector extenders. Position the flexible trim flush with the top of the air deflector extender. Secure the trim in position with one #10-16 x 1-1/4" self-drilling pan hd. screw in the center of the molding. Tighten the screws to 6 ft-lbs. (8 N•m). DO NOT OVER TIGHTEN.

Hold the air deflector extender in position against the back of the roof air deflector with "C" clamps. Position the extender so it is even with the top and flush with the outer edge of the roof air deflector.
Use the three holes in the extender as a template and drill 11/32" holes through the roof air deflector in these locations.

Secure the air deflector extender to the back of the roof air deflector with three 5/16"-18 x 1-1/4" bolts, 5/16" flat washers, special washers and lock nuts in the three drilled holes as illustrated in view B-B, Figure 15. Tighten the fasteners to 18 ft-lbs. (24 N•m). Repeat this procedure on the opposite side of the roof air deflector.

Install the roof fairing extender brace between the rear of the roof air deflector and the air deflector extender as illustrated in views A-A and C-C, Figure 15. Tighten fasteners to 18 ft-lbs. (24 N•m).

Install the side rear upper air deflector mounting brackets between the upper and lower side mounted air deflectors with 5/16"-18 x 1" SST hex hd. bolts and 5/16" lock washers as illustrated in view "D", Figure 15. Tighten all fasteners to 18 ft-lbs. (24 N•m).

At the lower end of the angle bracket on the air deflector extender is a hole. Make sure the lower end of the extender is flush with the outside of the roof air deflector and install a #10-16 x 1-1/4" self-drilling pan hd. screws in this hole, into the back of the fiberglass roof. Tighten to 6 ft-lbs. (8 N•m). DO NOT OVER TIGHTEN.
Repeat this procedure on the opposite side of the roof air deflector.

svcproc.title: PRIME AND TOPCOAT PAINTING FIBERGLASS
svcproc.para: The SIKKENS Technical Data Sheets referred to in this document are located in Group 16 - PAINT in the CTS-5000 Master Service Manual.

step1.para: Wash part with lacquer thinner.

Degrease the part with SIKKENS M600 WAX and GREASE REMOVER. Use two cloths: the first with M600, the second dry, as a wipe on and wipe off process. Follow the directions listed in SIKKENS Technical Data Sheet 6.27.

warning.para: To prevent personal injury when sanding and applying paint, use an approved mask for the type of operation being performed.

step1.para: Scuff the entire panel with Scotch Brite 7447.
Remove dust by using air blow off.
Degrease again using SIKKENS M600 WAX and GREASE REMOVER.
Mix 100 parts AUTOCRYL FILLER OFF-WHITE with 50 parts of AUTOCRYL 1.2.3 HARDENER and 30 parts SIKKENS 1.2.3 REDUCER according to the directions in SIKKENS Technical Data Sheet 3.2.6.
Use tack cloth to remove remaining dust.
Apply mixed AUTOCRYL FILLER OFF-WHITE following the instructions in the Technical Data Sheets.
Allow to dry a minimum of 15 minutes at 70°F before applying topcoat paint. If primed part sets longer than one hour, sanding is required to assure topcoat adhesion.
If sanding is required, use #360 - #400 grit paper dry or #500 - #600 grit wet. After sanding, degrease the surface with M600 WAX and GREASE REMOVER.

If surface quality of the primed part is not acceptable due to pits or waviness, the defects may be repaired by using SIKKENS POLYKIT, POLYSTOP LP. Follow the directions in SIKKENS Technical Bulletin 4.5.3. When the POLYSTOP LP is cured, sand smooth with #240 - #320 grit paper dry and reprime the entire piece following steps 4 to 10. Wear an approved dust mask. The repaired area can also be spot primed following the instructions in the Autocryl Filler Technical Data Sheet 3.2.6.

If the appearance of the primed part is unacceptable because of glass pattern read through, thoroughly sand the entire surface with #360 - #400 grit paper dry or #500 - #600 grit paper wet. Wear an approved dust mask. Degrease again using SIKKENS M600 WAX and GREASE REMOVER. Reprime the entire part following Steps 4 to 10.
Use tack cloth to remove remaining dust.
Topcoat with SIKKENS Autobase/Clearcoat system following the instructions in SIKKENS Technical Data Sheet 5.2.11.

svcproc.title: CLAIM FOR CARRIER LOSS OR DAMAGE

step1.para: You must give shipments that are being delivered to you a CAREFUL COUNT and INSPECTION. The following should be carefully checked:

item.para: Actual count of the goods and comparison of that count with the number of pieces listed on the carrier's freight bill.

step2.para: Usually the piece count is of prime concern to the receiver and carrier. Piece count is important, but of equal importance are the labels or markings on the freight that is being offered to you. Each individual shipping container should be checked to make sure that the cartons are really consigned to and marked for your company.

The carrier presents you with a freight bill which specifies the number of pieces you are supposed to receive. Be sure that you receive the number of pieces indicated on the carrier's bill. Be sure that the driver agrees with your count of the number of pieces received.

If a shortage does exist, and you and the driver agree to this fact, then be specific as to the description of that shortage on the carrier's bill. Rather than note the carrier's bill as "1 carton short" state the shortage as specifically as possible, such as: "1 carton AM - FM radio model 123 short." Remember, under law, the bill of lading is the governing document, not the purchase order or shipping invoice.
Examine each container for signs of damage or mishandling.

If the container is damaged in such a way that you suspect there may be damage to the contents, then demand that the containers be opened and the content inspected. You and the driver jointly inspect the contents for damage. If there is damage to the contents, then note the bill as "1 model #123 desk, container or carton damaged, desk has a broken drawer front."

There is another aspect which must be addressed, and that is refusing to accept damaged goods. The law is clear that only if a shipment is damaged and practically worthless are you legally justified in refusing to accept shipment. The law is also clear that you must accept partially damaged shipments and take necessary measures to mitigate the loss.

It is good business practice to request an inspection be made by a carrier's representative (other than the driver) after delivery, and when you have had the opportunity to examine closely the damaged goods and review your options for mitigation.

Every effort should be made to unpack and inspect all merchandise for damage as promptly as possible. The full inspection should be made within 15 days after delivery. The rules and regulations concerning concealed damages have been set forth in the Interstate Commerce Commission's ruling under Ex Parte 263, and item 300135 of the carrier's classification states, in part, "It is incumbent upon the consignee to offer reasonable evidence to the carrier's representative when inspection is made that loss or damage was not incurred by the consignee after delivery of shipment by carrier."

note.para: Inspections are not claims; you must still file a proper claim of which the inspection report is a part.
If you find concealed damage, you must take the following steps:

step3.para: When damage is discovered, retain the original shipping containers and all packing devices. You should also take precautions to protect the goods from further damage and attempt to retain the goods and containers in the area where damage was first discovered.

Call the local office of the delivering carrier. Speak to the OS&D clerk, loss prevention, or customer service manager. If you are calling the corporate office of the carrier, ask to speak with the claims department. Be prepared when you call to give the specifics of the situation:

item.para: The value of the damaged commodity

step3.para: Explain that you are requesting an inspection of the goods. Be sure you get the name of the person to whom you are speaking and make a note of the call for your records. Under the rules of the ICC and the carriers classification, the carrier has five working days to make the inspection (excluding Saturdays, Sundays and Holidays). Immediately after you have made your call, follow up with a written letter or memo to the person with whom you made the request.

step2.para: In some instances, the carrier may waive its right to inspect the goods and will so advise you. This waiver does not mean the carrier has waived its right to salvage the goods. In case of waiver, then you should prepare your own inspection report, which though not jointly made will not jeopardize your recovery. Be certain to record the date that the waiver is received, and the name of the carrier's representative making the waiver. Be sure to ask for written confirmation.

There is little formal procedure in the area of salvage of goods, other than you must retain them for the carrier, if worthless, or mitigate the damage by repair or discount sale. It is the usual procedure that a carrier will take no formal action until a claim is filed. Do not dispose of the salvage or damaged goods without communicating with the carrier.

step1.para: Under the National Motor Freight Classification, item 300110, the following are the documents REQUIRED to document properly and support your claim.

item.para: Original copy of carrier's freight bill.
The bill of lading covering the shipment (or bond of indemnity in lieu thereof).
If discounted, a copy of the bill of sale or sales receipt.
If an inspection was made, a copy of the inspection report.
Any other information that may assist a carrier to investigate properly your claim.

step1.para: Your claim can be filed with either the origin carrier or the delivering carrier, preferably with the carrier's corporate office, rather than the local carrier.
There are several limitations of which you should be aware. These limitations have been outlined in Ex Parte 263 with regard to inspection requests; however, there are two other time limitations.

step2.para: You have nine months from the date of delivery in which to file your claim, or if for non-delivery, then you are allowed nine months plus a reasonable delivery time.
If your claim was denied by the carrier, you have two years and a day from the date of the carrier's declination to bring suit for recovery.

step1.para: Remember that it is YOUR RESPONSIBILITY under law to prove the carrier was liable for the loss or damage in handling of your goods. The mere fact you have filed a claim does not mean the carrier must pay. YOU MUST present documentation to prove your case. Under the bill of lading contract, the carrier has only agreed that he has "delivered the goods described in apparent good order, contents and conditions of content unknown." Likewise, when you sign a carrier's freight bill, you have signed a receipt that states or implies, "received in apparent good order, except as noted." Your case for recovery begins with the receipt of the goods.
